Line 3: Line 3:
Their location in the sky as observed from Earth's surface would be fixed at about 60 degrees east and west of the Sun, and as people tend to search for asteroids at much greater elongations few searches have been done in these locations.
Their location in the sky as observed from Earth's surface would be fixed at about 60 degrees east and west of the Sun, and as people tend to search for asteroids at much greater elongations few searches have been done in these locations.
â
The 300m diameter asteroid [[2010 TK7]] has been located in the Earth {{L4}} Lagrange point, leading the orbit of the Earth, by [[Martin Connors]] and colleagues of [[Athabasca University]] using the [[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE)]] satellite. It is the first confirmed Earth Trojan.<ref>http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg21128234.200-earth-stalker-found-in-eternal-twilight.html</ref>
+
The 300m diameter asteroid [[2010 TK7]] has been located in the Earth {{L4}} Lagrange point, leading the orbit of the Earth, by [[Martin Connors]] and colleagues of [[Athabasca University]] using the [[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer|Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE)]] satellite. It is the first confirmed Earth Trojan.<ref>http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg21128234.200-earth-stalker-found-in-eternal-twilight.html</ref>
Earth has a second companion, asteroid [[3753 Cruithne]], about 5 km across, in a peculiar type of orbital resonance called an [[Horseshoe orbit|overlapping horseshoe]]. It is probably only a temporary liaison.<ref>Murray, C., âThe Earthâs secret companionâ, Nature 387, 651-652 (1997)</ref> Several other small objects have been found in similar orbits. While these objects are in 1:1 orbital resonance, they are not Earth Trojans because they do not occupy the {{L4}} or {{L5}} [[Lagrangian point]]s.
Earth has a second companion, asteroid [[3753 Cruithne]], about 5 km across, in a peculiar type of orbital resonance called an [[Horseshoe orbit|overlapping horseshoe]]. It is probably only a temporary liaison.<ref>Murray, C., âThe Earthâs secret companionâ, Nature 387, 651-652 (1997)</ref> Several other small objects have been found in similar orbits. While these objects are in 1:1 orbital resonance, they are not Earth Trojans because they do not occupy the {{L4}} or {{L5}} [[Lagrangian point]]s.
